definition:
Among the surfaces $F(x,\,y,\,z) = 0$, with $F$ twice continuously
differentiable, a [*minimal surface*]{} is such that in every of its
points, the mean curvature vanishes. Because the mean curvature is the
arithmetic mean of the principal curvatures $\varkappa_1$ and
$\varkappa_2$, the equation $$\varkappa_2 \;=\; -\varkappa_1$$ is valid
in each point of a minimal surface.

A minimal surface has also the property that every sufficiently little
portion of it has smaller area than any other regular surface with the
same boundary curve.

Trivially, a plane is a minimal surface. The catenoid is the only
surface of revolution which is also a minimal surface.
